Bong Joon-ho's The Host is the best kind of genre film, a movie that delivers the conventions audiences expect from a horror flick while also offering surprising new variations on the formula.
The director has taken a depressing topic and used it as the basis for the most exhilarating movie so far this year.

Epic Movie is a comedy that is so spectacularly bad in so many ways that it's almost awe-inspiring -- at every point in the film, every creative choice seems to have been made for precisely the wrong reason.
It combines the emotional impact of great drama with the precision, detail, and context of great journalism, resulting in a vital and rewarding moviegoing experience.
Norbit is a return to form for Murphy; while it's not on a par with his best work, it's very funny and just risky enough to eradicate the memory of Daddy Day Care.
The wait is over. Endlessly imaginative, rigorously crafted, and extremely frightening, Behind the Mask is as good as horror gets.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Messengers is still worth seeing for the strength of its first half and for the consistently solid performances, but the sense of unrealized potential is tough to ignore.

Characters are so imprisoned by the movie's need to drive home its antislavery message that they become utterly lifeless. Pretty pictures abound in Amazing Grace, but they don't serve to illustrate any ideas or emotions worth wrestling with.
While the end result of all this experimentation isn't entirely convincing or coherent, it's fairly entertaining and will probably appeal to the young audience at which it's aimed.
A real downer of a comic book movie.

With its quiet, unassuming style and brooding intelligence, First Snow isn't the kind of movie that announces itself, but it's well worth seeking out, especially for moviegoers who complain that 'they' don't make movies for grown-ups anymore.
If Tortilla Heaven is supposed to be a more serious exploration of faith and greed it's a total failure, given that it doesn't address a single question it raises with any depth.
the bottom line is that Kazi and his cohorts would be even better served by a film that was more than only intermittently involving, and The Hip Hop Project is not that film.
An unadulterated modern-day classic.
The creators of The Reaping don't believe in their own pro-spirituality message, which they're willing to betray in the film's final minutes for the sake of one cheap, totally gimmicky scare.
An instant cult classic.
Their amorality isn't presented in a conventional manner; it's depicted in an unremarkable, matter-of-fact style that makes it all the more realistic -- and all the more unsettling.
Essential viewing.
It wants to be Hostel for nice, respectable folks, an objective that ultimately seems to be rather pointless in spite of the obvious talent behind and in front of the camera.
Educational, but it's also an enjoyably goofy comedy that will appeal to fans of Mad TV and Saturday Night Live.

Some of the characters' problems are wrapped up a bit too neatly, but the mild contrivances work because the principles are so endearing -- we want them to be happy, so when they are, it's satisfying, even if the happy moments aren't so honestly achieved.
A sequel to a remake that's surprisingly intelligent and original, and it proves to be a worthy successor to both Alexandre Aja's 2006 Hills and Wes Craven's 1977 original.
Perfectly serviceable middle of the road comedy.
Penn isn't quite as charming here as he was in Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle, but he has a lot less to work with.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Heart of an Empire is a funny and touching love letter to a group of men and women far more complex than they initially appear.
Compressing Obree's story into an hour and a half makes it seem less astonishing than it actually is -- the triumphs seem too easily won, and the problems too quickly resolved.
De Palma and Scorsese breathed new life into the crime genre; Silvera just embalms it.
Asif Kapadia's The Return is a visually sumptuous but emotionally stillborn thriller that may be a bit too modest for its own good.
The intimacy and immediacy of digital video has allowed Lynch to make his most personal film yet, and the result is one of the richest and most rewarding moviegoing experiences of 2006.
This perfectly paced, thoughtfully written, and impeccably acted masterpiece is a gourmet meal from one of American cinema's master chefs.

Let's Go to Prison announces its desperation right from the opening credits, thanks to a montage of celebrity mug shots and arrest footage suggesting there are still laughs to be had at James Brown and Martha Stewart's expense.
[Director Nacho] Cerdà's craftsmanship and his overall sense of seriousness keep The Abandoned from being a bad film, but it simply isn't very scary or involving. It just feels too familiar and dull.
3 Needles is difficult to take at times, but it ultimately rewards those viewers willing to meet its challenges.
In its own low-key way, 10 Items or Less is completely satisfying, and as a showcase for a great veteran actor and a gifted young actress, it's essential viewing.
The sheer volume of intense emotional content has a cumulative effect that will easily win over anyone whose heart and mind are open to it.
...Off the Black is a low-key, but powerful drama that allows some great actors to do what they do best.
An escapist romp, pure and simple, and Carnahan's aggressive style keeps it entertaining even when there's no underlying point.

Rocky Balboa is not only the best sequel since Terminator 2 and the best movie of writer-director-star Sylvester Stallone's career, it's one of the best American films of 2006, and the year's most pleasant surprise.

The sheer technical brilliance of the battle sequences and martial arts showdowns is mind-blowing -- this is the kind of movie that's so visually dynamic that it's compelling even when we could care less about the people on screen.
Morgan's gleeful desire to shock the audience both with the gore and the perverse backstory is delightfully infectious.
The routine story and lack of real warmth make this a movie to endure with one's children, not to share with them.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The outstanding performances and writing would make a great film even if all [Karen] Moncrieff did was turn on her camera and aim it at the actors, but she adds yet another layer of meaning to the piece via her thoughtfully considered visual style.
The emotional void at the film's center grows larger and larger, until in the movie's penultimate scene even a depiction of graphic mass sexuality fails to be particularly exciting or interesting.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Winkler clearly loves these characters, and if he sometimes pushes too hard in his effort to make the audience share his affection it's forgivable under the circumstances.
Family Law [is] one of the best examinations of [fathers and sons] ever committed to celluloid.
Thr3e is an eccentric combination of horror film and religious morality play that isn't entirely successful on either level but gets by on the sheer professionalism of its makers.
Ultimately Alpha Dog is most successful as a teen gangster movie, a kind of cross between Goodfellas and The O.C. that is swiftly paced and extremely compelling.
It's a pretty tasty bit of cinematic junk food.

Though the plot is close enough to the 1986 version to earn a screen credit for that film's scriptwriter, Eric Red, the execution is so botched that what was terrifying in the original film becomes coma-inducing in the remake.
So much time is wasted on irrelevant material that the movie drags at a snail's pace, and even at 141 minutes, Letters never develops its ideas beyond the standard 'war is hell' clichés.
An accessible piece of entertainment that you don't need to shut your brain off to enjoy.
Who would have thought that the director of the violent revenge flick Mad Max would go on to create some of the most charming children's films since Walt Disney?
The fact that Blind Dating provides a relationship between two characters whom the audience desperately wants to see wind up together is ultimately all that matters.
Idiosyncratic and personal, it's a comedy that could only have come from the distinctive mind of its very talented creator.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's a two-minute trailer unsuccessfully stretched into an 87-minute feature film.
It's admittedly pretty dumb, but in the end its fierce commitment to its own goofy ideas is oddly admirable.
In the end, the scariest thing about The Last Winter is how few of its ideas seem truly fantastic or implausible.
Pathfinder is simultaneously action-packed and a total bore, a strange movie that never seems to move even though it consists of almost nothing but violence.
The movie has more power than a conventional adventure film because it has more to say.
Uplifting and enraging in equal measures, Bill Haney's The Price of Sugar is a powerful issue-driven documentary that also happens to have one of the most compelling heroes of any movie this year.

Moyle is as deft a craftsman as ever, utilizing the widescreen frame to create a number of elegant, vibrantly colorful images that give the film a bright, bubbly energy in spite of the violence at its core.
Joel Edgerton's debut feature as director, The Gift, is the best kind of great movie: It doesn't announce itself as great at all.

Peter Bogdanovich's She's Funny That Way is simultaneously everything one might expect and a complete surprise, a film that contains all of the strengths of the director's past work in a completely new form.
Sets out to reinvent the genre only to succumb to all of the same old formulas.
The Perfect Guy is pitch-perfect Hollywood entertainment of the kind that studios used to crank out by the dozens in the 1940s.

This is a movie of supreme confidence -- it starts strongly and only gets better in every scene -- a thriller that invites plenty of comparisons to the works by masters of the form: Hitchcock, Polanski, De Palma. It earns these comparisons.
It must be noted that few American directors, and virtually none in the studio system, are tackling the kinds of difficult questions that [Spielberg] routinely addresses head-on.
Truth is one awfully glib piece of work.
Goosebumps is the first film I've seen that actually recreates the charm of something like The Goonies or Gremlins and successfully updates it rather than merely imitating it.
A lively, spectacularly entertaining documentary by filmmaker, archivist and historian Kent Jones.
[Stone's] latest film, Snowden, synthesizes all of the director's best qualities into one ruthlessly efficient 134-minute package.
This is Cassar's second film this year -- the first was the exquisite Western Forsaken -- and confirmation that he's a filmmaker of uncommon talent and versatility.

A sloppy, careless mess which takes forever to get where it's going and has no idea what to do when it gets there, Sharon Maguire's return to the Bridget Jones franchise is still fairly watchable thanks to the charisma of its three leads.

Kleber Mendonca Filho has made only two features, but with his second, Aquarius, he achieves artistic heights common only to the masters of the medium: Jean Renoir, Yasujiro Ozu, Ingmar Bergman, Abbas Kiarostami, Richard Linklater.

In Fink's script for The Last Word, Pellington finds the right vehicle to explore his preoccupations through a new lens, and addressing the issues through female characters has reinvigorated his technique.
A provocative, unsettling tale about a powerful nation on the defensive.
Monty Lapica's Self-Medicated is a powerful, personal piece of independent filmmaking

Rob Zombie's remake of John Carpenter's Halloween is neither the blasphemous affront hardcore fans have feared nor the flat-out masterpiece one might have hoped for from one of modern horror's most distinctive talents.
The superb craftsmanship on display only makes the film's shortcomings more frustrating, though; it's one of the best-looking boring movies ever made.
Heartbreak has been portrayed on film many times, in many ways, but Hawke and his actors find a whole new language for it.

Like John Cassavetes and Martin Scorsese, Jaglom knows how to push a scene into realms of such emotional nakedness that the viewer starts to feel like a voyeur looking in on relationships that are none of his or her business.
Like its villain, its brute strength makes up for its relative lack of brains.
That they've assembled a first-rate cast made up of veteran character actors and contemporary comedy stars to pursue this agenda makes The Wendell Baker Story all the more effective.

Beautifully made but simple-minded Oscar bait, a film guaranteed to offend no one and to attract a large contingent fans who will love it for the nobility of its intentions and the earnestness of its performances.

One of the most surprising things about the movie is how much fun it is. The story Minygululu tells has components as exciting as any American action movie, and the relationships are as compelling as the best melodrama.

Night Watch was a deliriously stylish and endlessly inventive rollercoaster ride; Day Watch adds emotional resonance to the mix to create an epic that's got more energy and depth than all three Lord of the Rings movies combined.
The uplift here is honestly earned, because it is so beautifully contrasted with harrowing venality and willful ignorance.
Hostel: Part II has something that most bigger-budgeted and more heavily promoted sequels don't: the ambition to not only repeat the experience of its predecessor, but to expand and improve upon it.

Williams's dialogue writing is often rather witty -- he's fully aware of some of the more ridiculous conventions of the genre, and he gives the characters exchanges in which they justify the plot contrivances in inventive, plausible ways.
Delivers exactly what it promises: it's a stylish, thoroughly entertaining summer monster movie.
Scary, smart, and moving, it's a terrific summer entertainment for grown-ups.
Consistently riveting thanks to the sense of sheer terror that infuses its best moments.

It alternates between bleak cynicism and a genuinely romantic sensibility, and this unusual combination makes the movie a great vehicle for Keaton and Valletta, and a compelling drama for the audience.
A weird hybrid of hipster art-house film and chick flick in which the warring intentions and attitudes cancel each other out.
The film is riveting at every moment even when the audience is a little unclear on how those moments connect.
Like its title character, The Real Dirt on Farmer John is a simple, effective movie with a lot on its mind.
movie_title: The Real Dirt on Farmer John (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Since the movie more or less abandons all pretense of naturalism somewhere around its midpoint, in the end the expressionistic frenzy of light, movement, and color that takes over is enough to make it worth seeing.
It's the best kind of documentary, in that if you're a thinking person it is nearly impossible to watch the movie without having your point of view challenged and questioned.
This isn't filmmaking it's shock treatment.
So lazy and so void of even the most rudimentary sense of storytelling that it showers the viewer with contempt...I've never felt as abused by a filmmaker as I did in Hot Rod.
The effect is not a rich film with a wide range of tones as the director may have intended, but a schizophrenic mess that ends up working as neither social message movie nor entertainment.
There's virtually no story in the movie, at least none that isn't utterly, completely predictable.
One of the year's more pleasant surprises.
Crosses our real-life national nightmares with a cleverly constructed thriller to create a movie that is smart, impeccably acted, and extremely unsettling.
Made up of moments that represent cinema at its best -- moments of pure sensation of the type that can't be expressed with the same degree of immediacy in any other art form.
With a decent and effective combination of touching, entertaining and often rather funny material, the film is one of those rare sequels that's as good and in many ways better than its predecessor.
Tarantino's attention to smart, witty dialogue, and the stepped up last half of the film make the feature worthwhile.
This is akin to The Three Stooges meet The Farrelly Brothers but taken down about a dozen notches or so in terms of intelligence, creativity or imagination.
Clearly not for all viewers, The Grey Zone is a thought-provoking but not quite believably realistic look at yet another saga of WWII era genocide.
Despite its obvious agenda, the film moves along at a good clip (clocking in at 80 some minutes) and should entertain adults nearly as much as the kids.
Manages to make the viewer feel the fear, pressure, frustration and success of making people laugh for a living.
It never has a consistent tone. In fact, it never settles on one or any particular genre for that matter.
A standard, run-of-the-mill drug drama.
Retreading a tired and worn genre, the film isn't the worst thing you'll see all year and it does offer a handful of laughs. Yet, it certainly could have been much better.
The film is mercifully short at around 90 minutes, but that won't make this latest cruise through the world of scary movies any more enjoyable.
Heaven has some good as well as disturbing moments, but isn't the cinematic nirvana that the title otherwise suggests.
Not perfect, but certainly intriguing and engaging.
Funny, well-acted and surprisingly engaging.
Hypnotically compelling in a car crash sort of fashion where one can't look away from the wreckage.
A solidly told and streamlined cinematic experience that's nothing short of gripping.
While the model turned actress certainly has the looks, body and sexy moves for the part, she simply doesn't pull off the more important aspect of the character, and that's the personality.
The filmmaker has delivered the most provocative film of the year that's also highly entertaining, thought-provoking and even moving (despite the obvious manipulation).
About on par with the first from a pure entertainment standpoint.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The film feels more suited as one of those old and educational after school TV specials than as a full-length feature.

While certainly not without its charms and clearly not a chore to sit through, the film isn't as fun or engaging as it should be.

Despite certain individual characteristics and plot particulars, [Kline's] character goes through most of the same motions we've seen before and then runs into a contrived third act that does neither him nor the film any good.
The film definitely has an audience out there. Yet, it beats me what they found so funny as what's offered is simply quite awful.
The effort features solid performances but also an omnipresent and gloomy realism that's likely to wear down and depress many viewers.
Too derivative for its own good (or that of the viewer) and simply not scary, suspenseful or intriguing enough in its design or execution.

Good for the fans but probably only so-so for everyone else.
A rousing good time that should entertain kids and adults alike.
Nothing comes as a surprise, and viewers will be pondering how certain things managed to occur -- especially involving the villain's apparent super-human strength.
Okay, but nothing great.

Features contrived, forced and far too obvious material in both its comedic and dramatically poignant moments.

The film is bad on just about every level.
One of the more entertaining and intriguing looks at dysfunctional people to come down the pike in quite a while.

Less than engaging and certainly choppy, increasingly melodramatic and, I hate to say it, but often amateurish, the film squanders its potential and makes one hope that Eyre isn't regressing in his filmmaking abilities and efforts.

This wonderful piece of work should bring a tear to your eye, a lump to your throat and ultimately a smile to your face in the end.

Worth checking out -- if you get can get past the material -- simply for being so different and intriguing.
Far too predictable, irritating and never engages the viewer.

The picture comes off as a decently made and thought-provoking little effort.

An entertaining diversion.

Not as abominable or excruciating as I feared it would be, but certainly nothing great, let alone classic.

With an above average number of jump scenes but only a few scant moments that are truly scary.

Although the subject matter will be abhorrent and repellent to some viewers, those who can accept or at least tolerate it will be in store for a tremendous piece of filmmaking featuring a mesmerizing story and an unforgettable array of characters.
With some okay racing footage but a dramatic story that becomes so leaden that it drags down the entire production, Biker Boyz doesn't get the viewer's engine racing as fast or as hard as it should.

A film like this also needs a great deal of double, triple and even quadruple crossing and confusion to be effective. Yet, it never really utilizes enough of that type of material to create the sort of experience for which it's obviously aiming.

Passable, but rather disappointing.
Messy, rambling and often as incoherent as the protagonist's fume-induced stupor.

Not as entertaining, engaging or enjoyable as it should be.

Deserving of ending up in the latter part of its title ...

Not atrocious, but certainly far from being as good as it might have been.

movie_review_blurb: Decent, but innocuous and offering nary a surprise or unexpected plot or character development, this romantic comedy doesn't possess enough of either obligatory element to appeal to anyone beyond diehard aficionados of the genre.

Passable but otherwise forgettable.

Fun and decidedly offbeat, but probably not for everyone's tastes or liking.
Nothing spectacular but nonetheless rather engaging and entertaining.
It's rather engrossing as one roots for the girls to succeed.

Fun, lively and meticulously crafted from start to finish.

Ranks up there with some of the best and most memorable pictures about the time, place and subject matter at hand.

Feels more like an experimental project designed simply to get under viewers' skins than a finished movie.
The film's tale is told so well and the performances are so on key that everything feels fresh.
[A] mediocre effort that doesn't really have anything new to say or explore, but is relatively easy enough to watch and should benefit from the current patriotic atmosphere in the country.
Yet another example of a vanity project and the old 'Don't quit your day job just yet' saying.

A mess of a film that may send you to the doctor for one or more of the following: Inducing the gag reflex, causing wrist strain from checking your watch too many times, or prompting temporary blindness from far too much eye rolling.

Certainly capable of entertaining the little ones and clearly nowhere as bad as I feared before seeing it, the film obviously isn't a classic, but it's an enjoyable diversion that most adults probably won't mind sitting through.
...stay far away from this film that's anything but what its title indicates.
Iris is a terrific picture that anyone who's loved or longed to love should see.
Neither scary nor smart, or even completely campy enough to be fun ...
... like a clever idea in concept, but unfortunately falls flat on its face.
Wears out its welcome and ability to milk its premise long before its runtime is done.

Despite its few flaws that prevent it from being a war movie masterpiece, this is still a riveting, engaging and even occasionally quite touching work that benefits from some terrific performances and technically well-crafted battle sequences.
Why not just go back and watch 48 HRS instead to see how this sort of film is done right.
The comedy -- despite a plethora of attempts -- isn't particularly funny, let alone hilarious, and the drama is laughably bad when not gratingly predictable.
It contains too many missed opportunities, mediocre storytelling and limp satire to be as good as it might have been.
If adult viewers go in with lowered expectations and don't mind the graphic sexual material, they'll probably find that this film offers enough of a different take on the standard road movie.
Unfaithful isn't the thriller it's advertised to be and isn't a good and/or original enough drama to compensate for that.
This is an outstanding piece of filmmaking that should be more than well-represented come awards season time.
While this is neither the first nor last time that will be the case, it is time to hang, gun down or lop off the head of this ugly cinematic series once and for all.
This popcorn flick promises little from an artistic standpoint but a decent time from a pure entertainment one and delivers a fair amount of just that.
A delightful piece of warm and cuddly escapist entertainment with simple and thankfully non-preachy life messages.
Decent and certainly not a terrible chore to sit through, the film offers some memorable moments.
For those looking for a smartly written character study featuring solid performances, you could do far, far worse than what this film offers.
Not a particularly good movie in general.
The film delivers what's expected of it, but unfortunately that's not much.
Decent, but nothing tremendous.
If repeated farting sounds, lame and disjointed comedy, and the name Pistachio Disguisey make you laugh, perhaps you'll find something redeeming here.
Despite its various problems that prevent it from being as terrific as it often seems it might be, the film is still quite entertaining.
Fine for his fans but a definite skip for most everyone else.
Too conscious of its own self...
Not quite as bad as when a black comedy swings and completely misses, the film thankfully isn't entirely awful or a complete embarrassment to all involved.
Overall, there's certainly enough of the familiar as well as the new to please fans of the series. For others, it's passable diversionary entertainment.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's the ultimate dumb but fun and stupid but often exhilarating summer popcorn flick.

A terrific pseudo-documentary that's so engaging, entertaining and fascinating that you won't notice its message of dealing with whatever life might throw your way. But you'll certainly feel it afterwards.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: LaBute has fashioned an engaging romantic drama -- but without his usual venomous behavioral qualities - that becomes increasingly better as it unfolds across parallel time lines and love affairs.

The presence of Bosworth and the terrific surfing scenes and amazing camera footage make the film worth checking out, especially if you love surfing or just watching Mother Nature's oceanic 'special effects' at work.
An uneven, hit or miss affair that never quite hits full Python stride and will probably only be appreciated by fans of one or both such music scenes.
For the most part -- and especially thanks to Aniston's performance -- it works more than adequately.
For a purported comedy, the film barely qualifies as funny, if even that.

If you enjoy your films served to the brim with testosterone and/or love the idea of a fight to the finish, you might find something redeemable here. Otherwise, don't expect anything along the lines of Rocky, Raging Bull or even Ali.
Superb from a technical sense but lacking somewhat in the all-important human element, Ridley Scott's war film is riveting, disturbing and likely to stick with viewers long after seeing it.

Nothing spectacular and not without its share of faults, the film works, for the most part, thanks to those performances and the strongly written, credible and realistic characters from which they stem.
Lame, disjointed and worse yet, not very funny.
Despite the conventional military spin on the old kill the dragon story, the film never really succeeds or goes far enough in being either a taut action thriller or purposefully over the top camp.
While not horrible, Men in Black II simply isn't as much fresh, entertaining or imaginative fun as the original.

If viewers aren't looking for anything remotely sophisticated and don't mind the broad, repetitive comedy or potentially offensive stereotypes, they might just find themselves enjoying this lightweight film -- to some degree.

Just entertaining enough to warrant a bit more than a passing grade, the film is better than Menace, but not by a great deal and still has too many glaring problems to make it as good or just plain enjoyable as it could and should have been.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Featuring a fun soundtrack, terrific writing, just the right directorial touch and some standout performances, this is a winning and highly entertaining comedy.
Certainly not a film for everyone, the film's good points outweigh and outnumber the bad ones.
Entertaining for kids (as long as it doesn't scare them) and thankfully short for adults, the film is by no means an animated classic, but it delivers the goods.
It's just too bad that so much of the film is heavy-handed, manipulative and contrived, or simply so hard to believe.
The result is a generally amusing diversion that retains enough of its pedigree to work, but one that lacks the punch and/or pizzazz to come off as outstanding.
The film is a solid, character-driven piece, with a terrific visual look and a good score, but it's not quite the brilliant, edge of your seat thriller that it seems it also wants to be.
One can't help but feel that either the filmmakers missed some golden opportunities or that the source material simply ran dry before the picture could run its course.
If you can manage to turn off your brain or at least the more critical and analytical part of it, this isn't a half bad political thriller.
Repetitive, flat and completely forgettable.
Obviously designed to entertain the general masses, the film has its winning moments and performances, but unfortunately contains just as many problems.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It seems that the filmmakers were so intent on getting the look and sound right that they forgot to put much effort into delivering an entertaining or even okay story.

For the most part, it thankfully succeeds rather well and comes off as an engaging and entertaining entry in the genre.
Whatever the truth, and despite some strong performances and a mildly creative way of interconnecting the various storylines, the picture is too much of a downer to be considered entertaining.
Nothing great and certainly not a classic, but nevertheless entertaining enough.
While not perfect, this sci-fi flick and its various scenes and sequences are likely to grow on viewers hours or days after seeing them, which is always a good sign.
A poor retreading of most every plot and character element from Tootsie.

Solidly told but ultimately rather mundane to watch.

movie_review_blurb: Not only is the film a mostly unimaginative and pale imitation of Beatty's version, but it's pretty much a poorly executed comedy in general.
These sorts of films are often hard to rate as they manage to entertain the little ones, yet aren't that well made from an artistic standpoint.

Just like most vertebrates in any world where gravity exists, however, a lack of a cinematic spine and skeletal structure usually results in a quivering mass that may look interesting, but clearly can't get anywhere on its own.
The sharp and witty dialogue is what makes the film.
The finished product posters may be alluring, and the cut may look promising while it's occurring, but in the end, you probably won't recommend the mediocre results to your friends.
Unfortunately loses steam and most of its senses as it progresses, turning what could have been a charming spy caper into a mostly painful mess.

Overall, the film is certainly interesting to watch ... It's just too bad that once the premise is set up, that the details of the mystery and the protagonist's attempt to solve it feel like a bit of a letdown in comparison.
Amiable but otherwise mediocre and redundant.
Too contrived and artificial for its own good.

An often riveting, cinematic experience.
Ultimately comes off as a clever idea that feels as if it wasn't fully realized.

The film may offer enough loud mayhem and onscreen activity to prevent a good, ninety-some minute nap, but it's otherwise just another redundant and mediocre film that steadily gets worse the further along it progress.
...nearly everything has incredible, subtle depth and this just make the movie that much more enjoyable.
Funny and entertaining.
Despite a fun and goofy opening, and a decent, if outlandish premise, the film squanders the latter and doesn't maintain the former, thus resulting in an overall lackluster comedy.

Had the film taken more of an edgy and irreverent approach - along the lines of one character's titular response, Breathe, Bitch to Waiting to Exhale -- it may have been more interesting and far more amusing and perhaps even insightful.
Although the film's not bad enough to be considered the cinematic equivalent of nails screeching down the chalkboard, it's simply too contrived and predictable for its own good.
While some of its individual, gross out moments will probably be remembered, the film itself is too easily forgotten.
While the picture contains no specific structural flaw or bad performance, it simply never manages to be engaging or compelling enough to overcome its overall bland and lackluster feel.

The movie is a ghastly, ramshackle mess, lurching from gag to clunking gag and exacerbated by Barry Peterson's harsh cinematography, making everyone look considerably older than they are.

Where Abrams left us eager for more, Johnson leaves us sated and willing to wait a couple of years for the next episode. Still, there's plenty of fun to be had, and the series faithful won't be disappointed.
Lawrence Sher's direction may be no more than workmanlike, but at least he stays out of everyone's way.
This franchise ran out of steam halfway through the credit crawl on the first movie, and there's been nothing but garbage-in-garbage-out since then.
A miscast and unappealing Rebecca Ferguson as soprano Jenny Lind sinks the movie even further.
The result is the kind of irresistible family-friendly fantasy that could wind up giving "sweetness and light" a good name.
It's just suspenseful enough to keep us wondering how it'll all turn out.
Director Babak Najafi gives a reasonable facsimile of the gritty atmosphere of the so-called "blaxploitation" pictures of the 1970s.

Roe tries for tortured angst, but his character comes off as an unlikeable lump, while young Fortson is saddled with college-age dialogue and the kind of twee precocity that moviemakers seem to think is so cute. And the music isn't all that hot either.
The movie avoids ruminating on America's Afghan policy, and ends before things get complicated, making it an upbeat movie about a downbeat war.
The young men do quite well, and Eastwood delivers a polished product with a tightly staged climax.

The story of the biblical strong man from the Book of Judges is drably retold without a trace of style or showmanship, making Cecil B. DeMille's 1949 Samson and Delilah (which was pretty good already) look like a masterpiece of great art by comparison.
Not that the movie doesn't have its charms even for non-soccer-fans-though they may want to duck out for popcorn during the big game. Those who love the game can nudge the rating up a notch or two.
That novel strain of black empowerment, and a powerhouse supporting cast ... are enough to compensate for all the usual cliches and paint-by-number action scenes.
McAdams and Bateman are the movie's only real assets; they're slumming, but they're having fun, and it's contagious.
The cast is generally good, but Rice's appealing sweetness is the movie's main attraction.
Rothe is the closest thing to a saving grace here; she has presence and wit and looks. If she can manage to drag herself clear of having to do junk like this, she may even have a future.
There's no getting around the fact that he's pretty damn funny. Even better than the concert footage is a framing prologue and epilogue in the form of a hilarious spoof of James Bond pictures.
The script by Paul Guyot and first-time director Dean Devlin putters around with leftover parts from disaster movies that were badly written in the first place, stranding a decent cast.
Considering that this cutesy-pie drivel couldn't possibly interest anyone over the age of 7, letting it babble on for an hour and 39 minutes is sheer madness.

McKinnon sports the worst Australian accent in the history of the acting profession, but it's still one of the best things about this no-class female version of Weekend at Bernie's Meets The Hangover.
Whether Lightning's midlife crisis will resonate with the movie's kiddie audience remains to be seen, but Fee and company get points for bringing it up at all.
Wright glosses over some plot points in the interest of getting on with things, but the car chases are the point, and they're terrific.
The story is all over the place-to the point where there's really no story at all.
The movie takes an idea with a slender thread of promise and does absolutely nothing with it, dissolving instead into unrelieved stupidity.
Marvel's latest reboot of this troubled franchise offers some new-toy fun for fans dead-set on a good time.
The story is slight but sufficient, and the fun keeps coming.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hawkins is the best reason to see this sluggish, pinched, claustrophobic little biopic; whenever it threatens to grow dreary, which it does often, the spunky light in her eyes draws us back.
The animation is candy-colorful, the pop-music soundtrack is catchy and the dopey puns almost pass for wit. On the whole, there are worse ways to waste 86 minutes.
The result is cold and unconvincing, by turns dull and repellent.
The movie is an utterly unique masterpiece, freighted with inchoate meaning and glimpses of eternity.
At 95 minutes it's just a messy sci-fi-horror-fantasy salad; King's "elements" become mere clichés. The actors and special effects crew do their best.
It's efficient but unsubtle; Lee and Prieto don't know the difference between real suspense and mere tension.
It's an unusual story unusually well-told, and performances are first-rate.

It has all the traits that made The Nut Job so completely pointless-complicated non-story, dull characters, lame sight gags, lamer puns-then ups the ante with an in-your-face nastiness, stomping and bellowing at the top of its obnoxious voice.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a sort of Flashdance for the Teletubbies set, not as obnoxiously atrocious as The Nut Job 2 (let's hope that record stands for a while), but really no better.
The movie's rewards are many, and its unforced sweetness disarms all misgivings.
Tom O'Connor's script doesn't know when to quit (half an hour earlier would have been smart); Jake Roberts' editing is sloppy; and director Patrick Hughes seems just along for the ride.
Acting at the top saves the day-by Corbett, old pro Barry Corbin as the town curmudgeon, and (especially) Nelson Lee as the leader of the refugees.
The upbeat ending rings false because (1) it feels tacked-on, and (2) the movie hasn't shown us someone who deserves it.
Marc Webb's direction is crisp and knowing, drawing fine performances all around - including from Kiersey Clemons as Turner's best friend and Cynthia Nixon as his doting mother.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Great look, great cast ... but everything just sits there like a tableful of delicious ingredients waiting for a master chef who never shows up.
Cranked out by an unruly mob of three directors and nine writers, this third outing is of interest only to kids ages five to seven-and any parents with serious daddy issues.
The movie's secret weapon is a possibly star-making performance by Tatiana Maslany as Bauman's girlfriend and later wife.
The cast and crew here are all hungry nobodies looking for their big break. They should keep looking.
The story moves with the predictable monotony of a Swiss clock that cuckoos every five minutes, and cheap jokes and wasted actors abound.
This sequel to 2014's Kingsman: The Secret Service is even more enjoyable than the original-though like that fun-filled spy-fest, it could profit from trimming 15 or 20 minutes.
O'Brien has an acceptable (albeit modest) level of charisma, Keaton adds gritty gravitas, and Cuesta keeps it all clipping along.
Nothing special, perhaps, but no disgrace either.
It's a harrowing story of heroism and dedication, and the movie does it full justice.
... the movie does have its little pleasures, in an adolescent high-school-drama-club sort of way ...
Hess deploys the same sneering derision he brought to Napoleon Dynamite; only Wiig eludes his heavy hand long enough to turn in a sensitive and sympathetic performance.
The result is harmlessly exhausting.
Michael Reilly Burke and Robin Tunney are good as Steinmark's parents, while as Steinmark's devoted high-school sweetheart, Sarah Bolger makes a mark for herself as someone to watch.
Echoes of better movies abound in Stephen Cyrus Sepher and Max Adams' screenplay, mixed with an illogic entirely their own.

A taut story well-told, suspenseful despite the fact that the world knows how it all turned out, and energized by an authentic sense of the dogged research and footwork at the heart of serious investigative journalism.
Ray builds an effective aura of menace and frustrated justice, with fine acting all around.

Expertly directed by John Crowley and adapted (equally well) by Nick Hornby from Colm Toibin's novel, this is one of the smallest, most intimate and best movies of the year, with an aching suspense that bigger, brasher movies can only dream of.
An unrelieved disaster.
As Reggie's emotionally fragile wife, Emily Browning is an oasis of sympathy amid the squalor, the only person in the movie we really give a damn about.
Measured and reverent as the movie is, it's also rather dreary, the kind of embalmed, oversolemn opus where the actors whisper their lines slowly, one word at a time.

Paula Pell's script is like a distended Saturday Night Live skit, overworking one lame joke: what if a bunch of forty-somethings threw the kind of party you only see in movies about hormonal teenagers?
It's a movie where very little really happens, and sometimes it feels as placidly shallow as the pools where the spa's guests soak themselves, but there's always something fascinating going on.
There are a few good laughs scattered about, but with these stars it should have been a lot funnier.
It's harmless enough, but harmless garbage is still garbage.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Like its predecessor, it's just as awful as it sounds.
The movie is a near-total dud, endless at 93 minutes, useful only as an intro to the strip for the benefit of those who have been in a coma since 1950.
Like the first two, it's stylishly pretty to look at, and the over-the-top fight scenes and visual humor (courtesy of directors Alessandro Carloni and Jennifer Yuh) are amusing.
It's a story tailor-made for Hollywood-it's remarkable that it hasn't been filmed before-but virtually everything goes wrong except the CGI and sound effects.
In the full movie, laughs are virtually nonexistent.
The movie violates its own internal logic and dissolves into worn-out slasher-flick tropes. Too bad; Menear and Bell had a bizarrely good thing going, but they couldn't come up with an ending.
It never rises to the level of garbage. Already we have the worst movie of the year-and maybe next year as well.
It's just another Hunger Games/Divergent/Maze Runner clone, with the heroine torn between two lovers.
The movie is a shapeless mess that lands with a pathetic thud.
Everybody plays straight man to Hart, who here is more grating and less funny than he was two years ago in the first Ride Along-and not nearly as good or as funny as he can be.
Dormer gives a nicely layered double performance as both twins-at least for the first hour or so, before the cheap scares and nonsense take over.
The story is beside the point in this pointless movie; it's less tasteless and offensive than the original, but just as god-awful.

Some of the jokes in Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick's script (from the Marvel comics by Rob Liefeld and Fabian Nicieza) are pretty funny, which helps compensate for the dreary familiarity of the CGI fight scenes.
It remains a puny little amateur-night rip-off of Sex and the City, without the saucy wit or sharply-drawn personalities.
Some hilarious facets of the true story are left out while much is invented, but the movie is an irresistible sports tearjerker.
Fey's resourceful, wry and witty performance-pulls us through time and again.
Tense and riveting, here's the movie some of us never knew Michael Bay had in him-the action, when it starts, is paradoxically both chaotic and clear.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cooper delivers the goods right enough, with help from Daniel Bruhl as his business partner and Sienna Miller as his sous-chef-cum-love-interest.
Grudges get massaged, secrets revealed, resentments flaunted, all punctuated with lame comedy and ending in the inevitable group hug.

At times the movie plays like a sluggish road company of Entourage.

Director Guillermo del Toro (who co-wrote with Matthew Robbins) serves up an amusing, sometimes hilarious parody of a Victorian Gothic horror story... Alas, the parody seems to be mostly unintentional, though it's not easy to tell.

Director Barry Levinson gives the movie a gritty veneer of realism and sun-baked menace, but Mitch Glazer's script is limp, unconvincing and vaguely distasteful, even despicable-a facile fantasy of stardom among honor-killing savages.
Elijah Wood, Rose Leslie, Michael Caine and Diesel are all wasted -- and so is our time.

The movie is trite, cheap and shoddy, designed to be watched on an iPhone instead of in a theater-plus, there's no way this assortment of bland nice-girls would ever become superstars. Not even on YouTube.

Hanks and Leckart tap into a latent nostalgia for Tower's free-and-easy heyday, and the movie is an intensely bittersweet experience for anyone who grew up with Tower Records as a home away from home.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The script by David A. Prior and director David Winters limply recycles bits of Dirty Dancing, Flashdance and other supposed classics of the 1980s.

This is a horror movie with a difference: It's genuinely horrifying, not just "scary." In fact, cheap scares are few, replaced by a mounting sense of dread and foreboding that gnaws at the pit of the stomach.
The inevitable sequel to 2013's guilty pleasure Olympus has Fallen doubles down on the guilt while losing the pleasure in sadistic monotony and narrative confusion.
Mostly the movie is simply dull, emotionally flat and so solemnly reverent that it's dramatically inert.
The script is trite and stilted.

The mind-boggling chutzpah of these two sleazeballs (plus Hill and Teller's strong performances) keep us watching in fascination.

The movie boasts strong performances by Chestnut and Hall (both of whom are always welcome)... Ultimately, though, all are undone by the tiresome familiarity of Jack Olsen's predictable script and Jon Cassar's limp direction.

This one is utterly, doggedly, defiantly undistinguished, designed only to play for a big opening weekend, cashing in on those millions of parents out there with nothing better to do with their kids on a Saturday afternoon.

The Hollars is no towering drama blazing new trails in the art of film. It's just a nice, decent little movie about essentially nice, decent people.

Moorhouse overdoes the quirk factor a tad, and there's a bummer of a development in the last act, but a clever plot and good performances (including Liam Hemsworth and Hugo Weaving) keep us engrossed in all the eccentricity.

Here's that rare sequel that improves on the original -- though you do have to have seen the original to be able to follow it.
Under Kirk Jones' laissez faire direction, the reunited cast shows such gusto that as before, resistance is futile.
The result is ugly in every sense of the word -- grimy, incoherent and a stupefying bore; everybody looks like they need a bath and the movie is as drained of fun as it is of light and color.

movie_review_blurb: One of the best movies of the year so far -- a riveting, white-knuckle thriller to rank with the best of Hitchcock, and an examination of the morality of drone warfare to rank with the polemical plays of George Bernard Shaw.

There's a fair whiff of Dawson's Creek Syndrome too -- teens sprouting eloquence and witticisms way beyond theirs or anyone's years and it can be a little too smug, smart and self aware.
It's a ruminative, universal exploration of grief and the life force that can flow from it. Quite literally, life taking over.
As Greg Focker might say, it's high time for this franchise to "Step off, bitch".
Wherever the truth lies, The Social Network is an innately compelling, beautifully crafted insight into the emergence of a global phenomenon and the disintegration of a rare friendship.
Shocking, provocative and poignant, GasLand is in short, compulsive viewing.
Watching Lebanon is more poignant armed with the knowledge that we're witnessing Maoz's own experiences as a young Israeli soldier during the war -- he's the gunner of the story.
Taken as a whole, if you allow yourself to take a leap of faith The Adjustment Bureau is an intriguing, engrossing experience. At the very least, it just might be the perfect date movie.
If Sagan is an underappreciated literary icon as the filmmakers imply, they've failed to restore her memory any glory with this underwhelming, uninspiring portrait.
A misstep, and comes across as a more self-indulgent and superficial effort.
Driven takes too many detours, and ultimately runs out of gas.
O Brother may be a long way from Homer -- and The Odyssey. But it travels well.
The 'Big G' is back, just in time, to save Japan by practically destroying it. To thrill a new generation. And to remind an older one of Saturday afternoons.
Craven hasn't lost his horror film touch.
It's rich in cinematic references and intermittently fascinating, but it's also frustratingly distant and strangely a little soulless.
Monsieur Lazhar never pretends to be anything but a grown-up fable, and it's a captivating one.
Let the haters hate, but Anderson continues to build a distinctive filmography on par with any of his contemporaries.
Provided that you can stomach its excesses, it's an unforgettable and weirdly rewarding excursion into violent fantasy.
Beasts Of The Southern Wild is an unforgettable film, filled with piercing ideas and images, even if it doesn't always have control of them.
Amores Perros is a yappy whelp compared to this striking degrees-of-separation drama.
Come back, Madea, and bring your chainsaw.
This is filmmaking of swaggering virtuosity.
Oh boy -- a shocker set against the terrifying backdrop of North Dakota sunflower farming!
An amateur-hour game of Spot That Reference, intended for people who crack up simply at the mention of anything topical.

If the film shows that few men are as unreasonable as Ralph Nader, it also shows that few have so succeeded in shaping their world: His legacy of progressive legislation will affect generations to come.
... make for gripping and confrontational viewing.
movie_title: Two or Three Things I Know About Him (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Switching the hero from a lone driver to a couple spoils the original's most intriguing idea: that the mass-murdering jackal may be the driver's own escaped id. That leaves little to fill 83 expendable minutes, which barely register as a movie.
The last thing a filmmaker named Nacho needs is more cheese.
The truncated stories force the actors to start at a high pitch and keep going, but they -- and the director -- work wonders at low volume.
Chabrol creates an unexpectedly humane portrait of bubble worlds in collision.

The chief problem with The Dead Girl, as with most current multipart films, is that the truncated stories don't give actors much room to develop a part. They're on-screen for such a short time that they act furiously from the get-go.
Maurice, the protagonist of Venus, is a suit lovingly tailored to O'Toole's ravaged but commanding frame.

Estevez means to eulogize the hopes of a nation, showing the night's impact on a group of hotel guests and staff cross-sectioned by age, race, and class. But his movie ends up buried under its stifling good intentions and dire execution.
[Bale's performance is] the kind of vein-popping show-boating that might as well be performed in a mirror.
[The] performances succeed where Harold fails: gaining a life independent of their author.
If writer-director Paul Morrison's film traces a predictable arc from racial unease to acceptance, it's often winning -- and sometimes tough-minded -- in the details.
Black Christmas lacks the timing and visual wit to make its splattery EC Comics gags either genuinely scary or funny.
The relatively tame horrors on display here may disappoint fans of the director's gut-spelunking short Aftermath, which made him an underground hero on the abra-cadaver circuit.

What narrative there is, along with a sense of incrementally mounting horror, emerges unbidden from the images-teeming streets that gradually thin, bundled proles panning for filthy water in potholes, stick-thin pedestrians stepping matter-of-factly past.
In his ghoulish documentary, director Eric Steel examines the Golden Gate's dubious honor as the world's most popular suicide destination.
Director Chalerm Wongpim's skull-buster makes up in wild-eyed insanity (and excessive, arbitrary slow motion) what it lacks in acting, pacing, and coherence.
Nothing illustrates the monstrosity of globalized commerce more vividly than the lateral tracking shot that opens Jennifer Baichwal's mesmerizing documentary Manufactured Landscapes.
Writer-director King deserves credit for wringing every ounce of ovine mayhem from his sheep-for-brains premise. There is no such thing as an unfunny cutaway to a sheep.
More than a vibrant experiment in ethnomusical cross-pollination, it's just great fun, tempered by loss but rippling with gusto.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe Judd Apatow's comedies also flatter the maturity-impaired by making their 10th-grade hang-ups lovable, but Apatow doesn't leave you thinking less of the women who abide them.

The filmmakers sometimes come off as smug jerks, but that doesn't mean they're wrong about the insidious impact of chain colonization, or the infernal effectiveness of something-for-nothing come-ons even in political pitches.
A gorgeous gravestone for the Beat Generation's legacy of beautiful-loser chic.

Stanley Kubrick's magisterial Thackeray adaptation now stands as one of his greatest and most savagely ironic films, not to mention one of the few period pieces on celluloid so transporting that it seems to predate the invention of cameras.
There's little beyond the surface-deep pleasures of this talky distaff riff on Wings of Desire.
If the sight gag is dead, this excruciatingly precious Belgian comedy is less a resurrection than an autopsy.

Expected ironies about homeland security, racial profiling, and fears of the Other land like a rain of anvils, and director Renfroe matches Krause's worked-up performance with a jiggly, flashy approximation of off-brand Tony Scott.
This ostensible comedy may be a new depths-of-hell low in the Emmanuel Lewis filmography, but for star Jamie Kennedy it's par for the coarse.
The makers of this self-indulgent autopalooza take a Ferrari engine, Porsche speed, Mercedes horsepower, and a Shelby Mustang chassis and somehow combine them into a Yugo.
Lowbrow plus highbrow does not equal middlebrow, and the breezy accessibility of Private Fears in Public Places does not make it any less a work of art than Resnais's more difficult early successes.

For anyone other than hardcore gore-hounds, this flipbook of deliberately invoked global-unrest horrors, from friendly-fire killings to rape as a breeding weapon, is effectively mean and unrelenting -- and pretty far from fun.
Is it written somewhere that every indie quasi-noir must include a dripping faucet, ceiling fans, shadows of slatted blinds, and a traveling shot of highway lines?
Dolls are innately unnerving, but the movie's semi-menacing Charlie McCarthys never live up to their potential.
The least concrete and most artificial of Buscemi's films. But that's as much because of the situation as Buscemi and David Schechter's slippery script.
The movie saves the full strength of her toxicity for a kicker that's almost gleeful in its sangfroid; Dercourt's parting coup de grâce is like getting shanked with an icicle.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Time perhaps scrambling it's for Alejandro González Iñárritu to stop his narratives.
This quietly unnerving psychological study from German director Hans-Christian Schmid wields its ambiguity about religion and science like a double-edged blade.
Padilha lays out the story with a crusader's fury while remaining careful not to slight the testimony or the suffering of Sandro's hostages.

Canadian splatter-movie auteur David Cronenberg was a lot more interesting when he made movies for drive-ins instead of arthouses, and this visionary horror film ranks among his most disturbing, provocative work.
If you hear cineastes discussing the film in hushed tones, it's only because Mitchum and Laughton have conspired to get under our skins and tattoo their story on our bones.
One of the great moviegoing experiences of recent years -- a work of staggering sadness, vitality, and comic invention that's as awe-inspiring a spectacle in its own unhinged way as Titanic.
At less than an hour, the film is a whirling delight, a kinetic overload of motion, elation, and unrestrained optimism.
Greenaway's characters may work fine as painting surfaces, but they have no interior life or independence that would arouse passion, and the director practically handles their couplings with tongs.
Price's hammy zest is what makes this such a nasty sweet.
movie_title: Theater of Blood (Theatre of Blood) (Much Ado About Murder) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Wong Kar-wai on aisle 4 and Michel Gondry on aisle 6, with Kevin Smith as mop jockey at all points in between -- such is the lost-in-the-supermarket milieu of writer-director Sean Ellis's whimsical comedy.
George Lucas is a wizard at populating a world with everything but people.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Buffalo '66 may be a mess, but often enough it's a beautiful mess.
You could certainly make a case for it as the great American movie, the one that best represents our character and our cinema, warts and all.
John Carpenter completists generally hate this slab of satiric sci-fi, but it's one of my favorite junk movies and a sure-fire Halloween rental.
Its mix of silliness, affection, and piercing nostalgia -- and yes, artistry -- keeps the separate halves of the audience engaged simultaneously.
Deeply unsettling.
No other movie makes being smart and cynical look like more fun.
The movie, directed by Rob Bowman, plays more to the show's chief strengths: its macabre wit, its creepy-crawlie scares, and especially the tense, complex relationship at its center.

Cronenberg makes leaps of logic, character, and setting so baffling that they don't become clear until the end. Even then, the final outcome is so devious you'll sit poking yourself to make sure you won't disappear with the click of the projector.
Perry's vaudevillian shamelessness and indifference to committee-approved taste are energizing and frequently jaw-dropping.
Don't Trip... amounts to a revival meeting with Harvey as both the pastor and the object of worship.
movie_title: Don't Trip...He Ain't Through with Me Yet (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Watching this zoo of long-vanished quadrupeds, you're left with an eerie message for our own warming times: They fought the thaw, and the thaw won.
The tone is pure eighth-grade AV-club infotainment.
Condensing years of filming down to 87 minutes makes every cut register with a pang of mortality: The temporal ellipses swipe away precious weeks and months in a flicker.
As with Brokeback Mountain, though, it's not the sexual content that seems revolutionary; it's the mainstream friendliness.

Perhaps you are wondering why a little-known band called Rocco DeLuca and the Burden merits a glossy feature-length documentary of its whirlwind European tour. After watching Manu Boyer's film, you may still wonder.
movie_title: I Trust You to Kill Me (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like the flailing airline industry -- which probably sent executives out for ice packs when they heard the title -- it gives you the ride you paid for, and nothing extra.
The filmmakers care; the actors try; the closing dedication is heartfelt and sweet. The movie, sadly, is an IV drip of artery-clogging Lifetime movie-of-the-week goo.

... director Ron Oliver applies a thin veneer of straight-to-cable pseudo-gloss without finding a workable tone, and the cast lacks the charisma and chemistry to make the genre and gender-bending register as more than novelty.
movie_title: Shock to the System: A Donald Strachey Mystery (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As a consideration of the power of storytelling -- and the urge to mythologize one's own life as well as the lives of others -- The Night Listener could serve as creepy paranoid cousin to the current Lady in the Water.
... the umpteenth prison drama to focus on the lurid threat of forced submission.

One for the time capsule -- not just as an irrefutable visual record of the size, diversity, and vitriolic fervor of the anti-Bush protest movement, but also as a demonstration of how unbridgeable the red-blue divide seemed in those dark autumn months.
Like the shambling VW van its hapless characters steer from Albuquerque to Redondo Beach, Little Miss Sunshine is a rickety vehicle that travels mostly downhill.
The movie's ultimately less interested in subversion than in sophomoric gimmickry.
It's been a long time since a movie got this much comic mileage out of the devalued reaction shot.
Spread the word: This delirious import is the most (maybe the only) fun action movie of the summer.
The movie's take on Southern-versus-Northern values could hardly be more stacked or slanted...
A wasted opportunity -- especially since the events as reported scarcely need embellishing.
The slicing camerawork of Fassbinder/Haneke collaborator Jurgen Jurges underscores the bitter message: We don't always know what we want from our parents, only what we're not getting.
The animation is exquisitely detailed, down to the lions' individually moving whiskers -- but when's the last time you enjoyed a cartoon for its realism?
A funny, inventive, ground-shifting hybrid of essay film, mea culpa, and pathological real-life romantic farce.
[The skilled voice actors] only underscore how misconceived the movie is on every other level.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Watch the mallrats' jaws drop as they pay to see the same old teen slicer-dicer, only to get this wacko hodgepodge of the Brian De Palma horror filmography and -- I swear to God -- Kieslowski's The Double Life of Veronique.
Bekmambetov's movie evaporates pretty quickly after it's consumed.

What makes the first fiction feature from documentarian Blitz persuasive is its late-film detour from the inspirational niche-sports genre to something altogether unexpected -- and the winning lead performance of Reece Daniel Thompson.
The doc's biggest revelation may be the extent of his stardom, even as he began to explore bawdy Jacques Brel chansons and psychedelic dada crooning.
Even though Vigalondo's obvious direction lingers over every carefully arranged tile in the toppling-domino plot, there's still some sinister amusement in watching them stack and fall.

Here's all fans need to know: Yes, Statham strips to the waist multiple times; yes, two dozen hopelessly outnumbered kung fu goons take on our lone hero one by one; and yes, he manages to outpace his Audi by bicycling through a congested sweatshop.
Every image seems to have been Scotchgarded.
More twee than any movie about serial murder has a right to be.
Even those who despise remakes will have to admit that director John Erick Dowdle's furious retread is scary as hell.

[José Padilha] recariously pitches the squad's brute force as less a necessary evil than the outgrowth of an existing evil -- a no-win situation that mocks liberal ideals and warps conservative pragmatism into domestic terrorism.
Rushed into production with no better drape for its threadbare gags than Cloverfield, this carpet-fouling mongrel of a movie no more deserves release than do anthrax spores.
The widescreen framing and saturated color make this one of Miike's most visually impressive features.
The resilience of the movie's subjects -- survivors of street crime and drugs and HIV -- irradiates Trouble the Water like sunshine.

Miller neither defends or apologizes: His remarkably candid footage (extending all the way to Wagner's deathbed and beyond) and interviews leave the man's sincerity (and his collectors') as open to scrutiny as his art.
movie_title: One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The directors prefer to secure O'Day's due as, in the words of critic Will Friedwald, the only white jazz singer who belongs in the company of Ella Fitzgerald and Billie Holiday.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Part caper movie, part real-life superhero saga, and entirely engrossing.
Even if you lose track of who's shooting whom and why during the abstract climactic face-off, the clever last shot shows you're not alone.
The Austin-shot movie catches the nation's mood of economic anxiety and workplace exploitation more pungently than anything else in theaters.
This 50-year-old film about a Los Angeles neighborhood on the skids and its barely tethered dwellers stands as the freshest movie in theaters.

While the evidence of his spotty post-1970s work is hard to refute, Gonzo proves what a vapid, overvalued commodity edginess is, championing Thompson's best work for brass-tacks insight more than brass-balled outrage.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Marley & Me proves how lifeless Lady and the Tramp would have been if told from the p.o.v. of Jim Dear and Darling.
A once-great director's near-worst work passes through its funhouse plumbing and emerges from the crapper as intentional mischief: self-sabotage explained away as mad genius.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The world may not have needed a Thai-language martial-arts hybrid of Kill Bill and Rain Man, but by God, it's got one now.

Proving that there's no statute of limitations on lousy ideas, director Andrzej Bartkowiak's attempted franchise expansion returns to the Capcom motherlode that produced the worst movie in the entire Jean-Claude Van Damme filmography.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Tex Avery cartoon of hyperbolic gore, which gets funnier with each disgusting new sight gag.
Birdman never falters as a love letter to actors, people who paradoxically remove their masks when they step onstage.
Son of Saul's achievement is to scrape away our benumbed awareness of the Final Solution in the abstract.

Control isn't just the formal rigor that Carol exhibits from the very first scene: It's the stifling exactitude required of its two main characters, whose every public utterance and gesture must be delivered in code.
Without the stunt, there's not much of a movie.
After a week of shameful anti-immigrant rhetoric, Brooklyn is the big-hearted bear hug of a movie a lot of folks could use.
A hugely promising feature debut for writer-director-editor Kimberly Levin.

The largely subdued movie could use a little obsessive visionary madness of its own, but Chris Nelson, the replacement guru, has an Opie-gone-Jonestown look that gets freakier as the movie progresses.
If you need an introduction to silent cinema, F.W. Murnau's 1927 milestone remains a piercingly direct universal drama.
movie_title: Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)

movie_review_blurb: This authoritative, far-reaching documentary by veteran investigative journalists Leslie and Andrew Cockburn comes off as curiously bloodless.
Micro in budget, macro in ambition, accomplishment, and scope, Adams's slyly withholding film prompts multiple viewings -- and deserves them.
Park's voluptuous style fits a genre that is all appetite -- or should be.
Scott's redo comes up short in almost every regard against the '74 model.
An unusually palatable entry in a rancid genre.
Neither a call to alarm nor a laugh-at-the-loonies yukfest, the doc charts a temperate middle course through its subjects' heated rhetoric.
[A] lugubrious thriller.
Not only the definitive American documentary about the war in Vietnam but a landmark political action.
For one ticket price, you get three shoddy Friday the 13th movies packed into one, which might constitute entertainment value if any one of them constituted entertainment.

The movie reclaims metal's appeal to the powerless as well as its threat--when you can get shot for wearing a Slipknot T-shirt (talk about "Death, be not proud")... raising those devil horns isn't an empty act of aggression.
The movie leaves open a provocative question: If you pick and choose which tenets of a religion apply to you, is it still a religion?

Movies tell the same stories over and over, but I know of only one that evokes mourned innocence in just a three-minute slow-motion shot of a Michael Jackson impersonator and a stuffed monkey aboard a clown bike.
For once, the movie -- written by Annmarie Morais and directed by Ian Iqbal Rashid with a gritty overlay of 16mm grain -- regards book learning as at least as important as physical prowess.
Credit writer-director Mitchell Lichtenstein with making a first feature that every man in America will watch with his legs crossed.
Walk Hard limps soft.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This burlesque of biopic cliches flounders from one setup to the next without the engine that drives the genre: a strong central character.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A medical thriller with a noggin full of novocaine, this shocker about a botched heart surgery evidently suffered brain surgery to match.

They [Rounders] stand as perhaps the truest heirs to the Harry Smith Anthology's wild and woolly Americanaâ"a point Sam Wainwright Douglas and Paul C. Lovelace's affectionate doc makes with a minimum of fuss and lots of bawdy hilarity.
As a study of stubborn artisanal tradition in the Pro Tools age, Note by Note is a stirring symphony of specialized labor.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This blast of homecoming claustrophobia is being released for the holidays, when it may prove therapeutic. Bring the family. Or better yet, leave them.
I'd be lying if I didn't say it overcame my naturally complacent instincts.
The Future Is Unwritten is less a eulogy than a wake, and one in which the subject is startlingly present.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Much of this is tedious -- no more or less exciting than surveillance-cam footage of a regional sales manager.
Do-nothing Sarah may be the dullest, most featureless and inactive protagonist in recent movies -- great news for those Scooby-Doo die-hards who never got enough Freddy.
movie_title: Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In his strikingly downbeat directorial debut, Affleck has created something of a blue-moon rarity: an American movie of genuine moral complexity.
It's the first of the agonizing Resident Evil movies that could remotely be considered fun.
In the Shadow of the Moon recalls the wondrous moment when America had the entire world looking up, up, and not away.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Pure straight-to-video rope-a-dope.

With the dithery Marion playing off Jack's nattering nebbish of negativism, Delpy invokes the Woody Allen-Diane Keaton chemistry of the '70s as consciously as Allen referenced the European art movies of the '60s.
The performances, culled from seven shows on the "Vertigo" tour from Mexico City to Buenos Aires, burn with the old unforgettable fire.
An unforgettable all-access pass behind the scenes of Bob Dylan's '65 British tour, D.A. Pennebaker's landmark 1967 rock doc all but invented the form while presaging the music video.
As vehement in its stereotyping as World War II propaganda.
Ever had a premonition of imminent catastrophe, only to watch helplessly as the worst unfolds? You have if you saw the previews for this snoozer of a paranormal shocker and bought a ticket anyway.
It's as relentless as it is hateful, hammily directed and derivative of the dreariest slop in contemporary American horror cinema.

Son of Rambow evokes the rush of discovery that turns budding cinephiles into lifers -- that delight in finding a film that seems to express or coalesce some inchoate yearning, including a yen to share.
Movies tell the same stories over and over, but I know of only one that evokes mourned innocence in just a three-minute shot of a clown bike.
A lip-smacking episode of Lifestyles of the Rich and Depraved, designed more for train-wreck gawkery than psychological illumination.
[A] searching, intellectually lively documentary.

Director/co-writer H.S. Miller just lays on the chilly blues and a wet-blanket mood of arty anguish, leaving cinematographer Fred Murphy and production designer Jackson De Govia to trump up trompe l'oeils of carefully posed carrion.
Floridly plotted but acutely detailed.
Bruce Van Dusen's 2005 comedy plots a meandering course due north without locating a word of truth.
Even the promising team of Peter Dinklage's mad scientist Simon Barsinister and Patrick Warburton's henchman Cad turns out to be a bust.
Pegg has staked out a peculiar slant on genre material that ventures beyond irony toward rehabilitation -- and nobody plays blithe humiliation with more style.
I still believe with all my heart that no movie with real car stunts, a tough-chick hero, and a severed head that thunks directly into the camera can be all bad. But this is pushing it.
Put Herzog at the same table as Hines, Harrelson, Parnell, Cross, and Farina, and poker on film starts to look a lot less dull. Imagine what they could do with Monopoly.
A modest surprise: better acted than needed, better made than expected.
The movie's glacial pace and willingness to let its mind and eye wander that produces its spiritual and intellectual heft-not to mention its atypical visual splendor.
[It] could pass for an episode of CSI: Reykjavik, only with less high-tech gimmickry, more pavement-pounding, and a head-clearing view of crime as anything but a cool diversion.
This uneven but impressive shot-on-digital shocker earns a marker in the mausoleum of apocalyptic horror -- a genre that's proving (un)surprisingly durable in the new century.
Forms, with Killer of Sheep, a landmark diptych about work as the crucible of the American characterâ"either in its abundance or its absence.
Despite the unhurried pace, the stories unfold without compelling details, and the interweaving is more pedestrian than artful.
movie_title: Bab'Aziz: The Prince Who Contemplated His Own Soul (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Staggeringly inane.
Men in Black has the right attitude toward movie technology: Get the most sophisticated special effects money can buy, and treat 'em like one of Ed Wood's paper-plate UFOs.
